patterns.name: Explainability
patterns.oneLiner: Show users why AI made a decision or recommendation
patterns.problem: Users don't trust AI outputs when they can't understand the reasoning. Black-box decisions create anxiety and reduce adoption.
patterns.solution: Provide clear explanations alongside AI outputs. Show the inputs that influenced the decision, confidence factors, or reasoning chain. Let users drill down for more detail.

examples.description: Shows reasoning steps in responses, explains limitations
Explains what it understood from the prompt before generating
Shows why each suggestion improves the writing

patterns.name: Confidence Calibration
patterns.oneLiner: Show users how certain the AI is about its output
patterns.problem: Users treat all AI outputs as equally reliable, leading to over-reliance on uncertain results or dismissal of accurate ones.
patterns.solution: Display confidence indicators alongside outputs. Use visual cues like percentages, color coding, or verbal qualifiers. Help users understand when to trust and when to verify.

examples.description: Shows multiple suggestions ranked by confidence
AI overviews indicate when information might be incomplete
Shows variation options when uncertain about intent

patterns.name: Source Attribution
patterns.oneLiner: Show where AI information comes from
patterns.problem: Users can't verify AI-generated information without knowing its sources. This creates credibility issues and potential misinformation spread.
patterns.solution: Cite sources for factual claims. Link to original content. Show what data or context influenced the output. Make it easy to verify claims.

examples.description: Inline citations with numbered sources for every claim
Shows source links alongside generated responses
Displays visited URLs and quotes from sources

patterns.name: Human-in-the-Loop
patterns.oneLiner: Require user approval before AI executes actions
patterns.problem: Autonomous AI actions can cause irreversible damage or unwanted changes. Users feel out of control when AI acts without permission.
patterns.solution: Preview AI actions before execution. Require explicit confirmation for impactful changes. Show what will happen and let users modify before proceeding.

examples.description: Shows suggestion inline, user presses Tab to accept
Generates content below selection, user chooses to keep or discard
Shows suggestion in gray, user presses Tab to accept

patterns.name: Undo/Redo
patterns.oneLiner: Let users reverse AI actions easily
patterns.problem: Users hesitate to try AI features when changes feel permanent. Fear of making mistakes reduces experimentation and adoption.
patterns.solution: Provide prominent undo for all AI actions. Maintain history for multiple steps back. Make reversal instant and obvious. Consider auto-save before AI operations.

examples.description: Cmd+Z immediately reverses any AI-generated changes
Shows 'Undo' button immediately after AI writes content
Non-destructive AI layers can be toggled or removed

patterns.name: AI Controls
patterns.oneLiner: Give users settings to customize AI behavior
patterns.problem: One-size-fits-all AI doesn't match individual preferences. Users feel powerless when they can't adjust AI to their needs.
patterns.solution: Provide toggles for AI features. Let users adjust creativity, tone, verbosity. Allow disabling specific AI behaviors. Remember preferences across sessions.

examples.description: Custom instructions for response style preferences
Goals panel to set tone, formality, intent
Settings to enable/disable for specific file types

patterns.name: Inline Feedback
patterns.oneLiner: Let users rate or correct AI outputs in context
patterns.problem: Generic feedback forms are rarely completed. AI can't improve without knowing what works and what doesn't for specific outputs.
patterns.solution: Place feedback controls directly on AI outputs. Use thumbs up/down, star ratings, or 'this was helpful' buttons. Make feedback frictionless and immediate.

examples.description: Thumbs up/down on each response with optional explanation
Feedback button on AI overviews
Accept/reject signals which suggestions were useful

patterns.name: Regeneration
patterns.oneLiner: Let users request a new AI output if unsatisfied
patterns.problem: Single outputs rarely match user intent perfectly. Users abandon AI features when first results aren't useful.
patterns.solution: Offer 'regenerate' or 'try again' buttons. Show variations or alternatives. Let users guide regeneration with additional context or constraints.

examples.description: V1-V4 variation buttons plus reroll for entirely new outputs
Regenerate response button, edit and resubmit option
'Try again' and 'Make longer/shorter' options

patterns.name: Memory & Personalization
patterns.oneLiner: Remember user preferences and context over time
patterns.problem: Users repeat the same instructions every session. AI feels generic when it doesn't learn from past interactions.
patterns.solution: Store user preferences, past corrections, and context. Reference previous conversations. Improve suggestions based on acceptance patterns. Let users view and edit what AI remembers.

examples.description: Memory feature stores facts and preferences across chats
Recommendations improve based on listening history
Learns from codebase patterns and accepted suggestions

patterns.name: Graceful Degradation
patterns.oneLiner: Provide useful fallbacks when AI fails or is uncertain
patterns.problem: AI failures leave users stranded with no path forward. Complete failures erode trust more than partial successes.
patterns.solution: Offer alternatives when AI can't complete a task. Provide partial results with caveats. Suggest manual paths or simpler requests. Never leave users with just an error message.

examples.description: Falls back to web search when it can't answer directly
Provides partial answer with 'I'm not certain' qualifier
Offers to set a reminder when it can't complete action

patterns.name: Error Recovery
patterns.oneLiner: Help users fix issues and try again after AI errors
patterns.problem: AI errors are frustrating when users don't know what went wrong or how to proceed. Vague error messages cause abandonment.
patterns.solution: Explain what went wrong in plain language. Suggest specific fixes or alternative approaches. Preserve user input so they don't have to start over. Offer easy retry options.

examples.description: Explains token limits and suggests breaking up long prompts
Explains content policy violations with guidance to rephrase
Shows why a prompt failed and how to modify it

patterns.name: Fallback Behaviors
patterns.oneLiner: Define what happens when AI is unavailable or slow
patterns.problem: AI service outages or slowdowns disrupt user workflows. Users can't complete tasks when AI is the only path.
patterns.solution: Design manual alternatives for all AI features. Show cached results when real-time isn't available. Provide clear status when AI is processing or unavailable. Queue requests for later processing.

examples.description: Smart Compose gracefully disappears when offline
AI features show 'unavailable' with manual alternative
Manual tools always available alongside AI features

patterns.name: Progressive Disclosure
patterns.oneLiner: Reveal AI capabilities gradually as users need them
patterns.problem: Showing all AI features at once overwhelms users. Complex interfaces prevent discovery of useful capabilities.
patterns.solution: Start with core AI features, reveal advanced ones over time. Use contextual hints to surface features when relevant. Let users explore at their own pace.

examples.description: Basic commands first, advanced options in submenu
Shows simple edit first, reveals more options after
Basic completions first, chat features introduced later

patterns.name: Expectation Setting
patterns.oneLiner: Clearly communicate what AI can and cannot do
patterns.problem: Users have unrealistic expectations from AI hype. Disappointment from unmet expectations damages trust permanently.
patterns.solution: State capabilities and limitations upfront. Use examples to show what good output looks like. Be honest about accuracy rates and failure modes. Under-promise and over-deliver.

examples.description: Welcome screen lists capabilities and limitations
Shows example outputs with prompt that created them
Docs explain it suggests code, doesn't write perfect code

patterns.name: Tutorial Flows
patterns.oneLiner: Guide users through AI features with interactive learning
patterns.problem: Users don't know how to get the best results from AI. Trial-and-error learning is slow and frustrating.
patterns.solution: Provide guided first-run experiences. Show example prompts and expected outputs. Offer tips contextually during use. Let users practice in low-stakes environments.

examples.description: Getting started guide with example prompts to try
Example prompts on empty state to demonstrate capabilities
Interactive tutorial showing how to accept suggestions

patterns.name: Prompt Suggestions
patterns.oneLiner: Help users craft better prompts with suggestions
patterns.problem: Users don't know what to ask or how to ask it. Empty text boxes create friction and reduce engagement.
patterns.solution: Offer starter prompts and templates. Suggest refinements based on partial input. Show examples of effective prompts. Auto-complete common requests.

examples.description: Starter prompts on empty state, GPT-specific suggestions
Related questions and suggested follow-ups
Style and parameter suggestions as you type

patterns.name: Structured Output
patterns.oneLiner: Present AI outputs in organized, scannable formats
patterns.problem: Wall-of-text AI responses are hard to read and use. Users miss important information in unstructured output.
patterns.solution: Format outputs with headers, bullets, and sections. Use tables for comparisons. Highlight key information. Make outputs easy to skim and reference.

examples.description: Uses markdown formatting, headers, code blocks
Structured answers with sections and citations
Organized responses with clear structure and artifacts

patterns.name: Multimodal Input
patterns.oneLiner: Accept multiple input types: text, voice, images, files
patterns.problem: Text-only input limits how users can communicate with AI. Some requests are easier to show than describe.
patterns.solution: Support image uploads, voice input, file attachments. Let users combine modalities. Show what input types are accepted. Handle each modality gracefully.

examples.description: Accepts text, images, files, and voice input
Visual search from camera or uploaded images
Analyzes uploaded documents, images, and code

patterns.name: AI-Human Handoff
patterns.oneLiner: Smoothly transition between AI and human assistance
patterns.problem: AI can't handle everything. Users get stuck when there's no path to human help. Abrupt handoffs lose context.
patterns.solution: Recognize when AI isn't helping and offer human support. Transfer full context to human agents. Make handoff seamless and preserve conversation history.

examples.description: Bot recognizes frustration and offers human agent
AI summarizes issue for human agent when escalating
Chat transfers to human with full conversation visible

patterns.name: Shared Context
patterns.oneLiner: Maintain context across AI interactions and collaborators
patterns.problem: Users repeat themselves when context is lost. Team members can't see what AI discussed with colleagues. Context switching wastes time.
patterns.solution: Persist conversation context across sessions. Share AI interactions with team members. Show what context AI is using. Let users add or correct context.

examples.description: AI can access page content and linked pages as context
Summarizes channels visible to the team
Uses open files and codebase as context

patterns.name: Version History
patterns.oneLiner: Track and allow reverting AI-generated changes
patterns.problem: AI changes can be hard to track. Teams need to see what AI contributed. Lost work from AI errors causes frustration.
patterns.solution: Log all AI-generated content and edits. Show version history with AI contributions marked. Allow comparing and reverting to previous versions. Make AI changes auditable.

examples.description: Version history shows AI-generated content
Page history includes AI edits
Copilot suggestions visible in git history

patterns.name: Loading & Progress
patterns.oneLiner: Show AI processing status and estimated completion
patterns.problem: Users don't know if AI is working or stuck. Long waits without feedback feel broken. Uncertainty causes users to abandon or retry.
patterns.solution: Show processing indicators immediately. Provide progress updates for long operations. Estimate remaining time when possible. Show what AI is doing if multi-step.

examples.description: Typing indicator while generating response
Shows percentage progress and preview as image generates
Step-by-step progress for video generation

patterns.name: Streaming Output
patterns.oneLiner: Show AI output progressively as it's generated
patterns.problem: Waiting for complete AI responses feels slow. Users can't start reading or processing until generation finishes.
patterns.solution: Stream text as it's generated. Show partial images during creation. Let users start interacting with partial output. Provide 'stop generating' option.

examples.description: Streams response word by word as generated
Progressive text rendering with stop button
Shows image progressively from blur to sharp

patterns.name: Scope Boundaries
patterns.oneLiner: Clearly define what AI will and won't do
patterns.problem: Users ask AI to do things outside its capabilities or permissions. Unclear boundaries lead to frustration or risky behavior.
patterns.solution: State scope explicitly in the interface. Decline out-of-scope requests gracefully. Explain why certain actions aren't available. Suggest alternatives within scope.

examples.description: Declines harmful requests with explanation
Explains when tasks are outside its abilities
Focuses on coding, redirects non-coding questions

patterns.name: Editable Output
patterns.oneLiner: Let users modify AI-generated content directly
patterns.problem: AI output is rarely perfect. Users need to make tweaks but can only regenerate entirely or copy-paste elsewhere.
patterns.solution: Make AI output directly editable in place. Track user modifications. Offer AI assistance for editing ('make this shorter'). Preserve formatting during edits.

examples.description: Generated content is immediately editable
AI text is editable with AI refinement options
Generated code can be edited in the preview

patterns.name: Contextual Triggers
patterns.oneLiner: Surface AI features when contextually relevant
patterns.problem: Users forget AI features exist. Hunting through menus to find AI options disrupts workflow.
patterns.solution: Show AI options based on user actions and context. Use selection-based triggers, empty state suggestions, and smart defaults. Make AI feel integrated, not separate.

examples.description: AI option appears when you select text
Smart Reply appears after reading messages
AI features appear in right-click menu for selections

patterns.name: Comparison View
patterns.oneLiner: Show original and AI-modified content side by side
patterns.problem: Users can't assess AI changes without seeing what changed. Accepting AI edits blindly risks unintended modifications.
patterns.solution: Display before/after comparisons. Highlight specific changes. Let users accept individual changes or all at once. Show diff views for text modifications.

examples.description: Shows original and suggested text with changes highlighted
Diff view for multi-line suggestions
Side-by-side comparison for rewrites
